marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Resident of St. Croix, Virgin Islands.

Contains comments to Campbell's mother in Philadelphia, Pa., about the trading firm of Coxe and Furman owned partly by Tench Coxe, an incursion of maroons (fugitive slaves) on Tobago, damage to the sugar crop on St. Croix, physicians on the island, the danger to commerce from British warships, and friends and relatives in Philadelphia and on Tobago and St. Croix.
Lawyer, legislator, judge, and member of the U.S. Congress, 1793-1795, from Milledgeville, Ga.

Personal correspondence written by Carnes while attending Congress, with comments on the affairs of the nation, Barbary pirates, John Jay's mission to London, and the attempt of the United States to maintain prestige among the European powers.
Originally from Dublin, Ireland; emigrated to Philadelphia in 1784 to escape legal persecution for writings critical of the British government. Father of Henry Charles Carey.
Collection consists of a letter form Joseph Priestley concerning two works that he was submitting for possible publication by Carey.

Collection contains papers principally relating to the indebtedness of the firm of I. and F. Gorin. They concern the collection of debts, the purchase and shipment of supplies (especially tobacco), and a creditor firm (John Gill, Jr., and Co.). There is also a partnership agreement between Campbell, Joseph P. Brown and John M. Shirley, by which Campbell was to furnish the capital and buy the goods for Brown and Shirley, store operators in Russellville, Kentucky.
G. Carpenter letter to G. D. Geese,

Letter concerns possible methods by which Carpenter could obtain money to repay a debt owed to Geese, such as through Carpenter's land speculation in New Orleans and his bid for sheriff, probably in Jackson County, Mississippi.
General merchant and cotton factor of New Light (Wake Co.), N.C.

Collection contains Cannady's business papers, referring to sales of cotton and purchase of goods for his store. Includes a personal letter from Elias J. Cannady while at school in Madison Co., Tenn. (1850). One volume is an account book, 1845-1865.

Chiefly letters from George Gilman Fogg and James Peverly in Concord, N.H., to Carlton in Bath, N.H., relating to New Hampshire politics. Primary among their concerns were the 1847 election of Jared Warner Williams, a Democrat, as governor of New Hampshire and of others whom they refer to as the "Hunkers." The letters reflect a strong anti-slavery sentiment and mention publications they believe would be supportive of their beliefs on slavery as well as other issues.
Confederate soldier, from Camden (Kershaw Co.), S.C.

Personal and business correspondence of John Cantey. An 1848 letter from J. Cantey discusses peace negotiations between the United States and Mexico. There is also an 1854 letter from Cantey to Gov. John Lawrence Manning concerning bank notes and endorsements. Civil War letters describe business conditions in Memphis, Tenn., in 1860, as well as secessionist sentiment in Arkansas, Mississippi, and Tennessee. Cantey's letters to his wife, Camille (written during his army service, 1861-1863), containing references to his experiences in the Confederate army. Topics mentioned inclue Morris Island, conditions in Horry County, supplies, troop movements along with S.C. coast, plantation affairs, runaway slaves, troop movements, procuring and making salt, and the scarcity of food.

Collection consists of a letter from Campbell to his son, accused of murder in Ala. The father believed that a runaway slave had committed the murder. Campbell then criticized Judge Benjamin Estil for alleged injustice, as well as for alleged personal misconduct and insanity. Estil was judge for the 15th judicial district of Virginia.
Professor of Greek at Trinity College (Randolph Co., N.C.), now Duke University.

Papers relating to the leave of absence of Carr from Trinity College for Confederate service, and his resignation from the Confederate Army because of ill health. Two items concern the financial affairs of Trinity College. Included also is a typewritten copy of Carr's journal, with scattered entries covering 1855-1878, although the great part of it relates to the Civil War.
"Elmwood," Union (Monroe Co.), W.V. resident. Caperton was the daughter of Allen Taylor and Harriette Echols Caperton.
Autograph album of a student at Virginia Female Institute in Staunton, Va. The album contains notes from classmates and verses of poetry.
Confederate soldier, originally from Cumberland Co., N.C.
Collection contains personal and Civil War letters to Campbell, a soldier stationed at Camp Leventhrop in Halifax Co., N.C; Fredericksburg, Va.; Petersburg, Va.; and Richmond, Va.
Graduate of Concord Female College, Statesville, N.C.

Collection contains family correspondence of Margaret Stockton Carmichael, largely dating from before her marriage to William W. Carmichael in May 1870. Includes letters from school classmates and friends at the Concord Female College, as well as Civil War letters. Following the war William Carmichael moved to Abilene, Kansas, to engage in the cattle business; the bulk of the correspondence is from him to Margaret during their courtship. Additional letters from 1871 document a visit back to Statesville following her marriage.

Collection contains an autograph letter from Carey referring to his unpublished tract "The Currency Question" (1865); two letters to Carey from John C. Hamilton of New York City commenting on a circulated pamphlet and speech; one letter from Carey (1860) responding to a query and referring to awaiting "the organization of the House, and consequent receipt of public documents."

Address delivered by A.G. Carr before the Durham Lyceum in 1882, entitled "The Immediate Past"; speech on Feb. 22, 1895 by George W. Watts presenting the first Watts Hospital to the citizens of Durham, N.C.; and the address of Dr. Carr in response to Mr. Watts.
Official and compiler of the "Bombay Gazetteer."
Collection consists of a letter from James MacNabb Campbell to [unknown] Codrington, discussing the Scythian invasions and rule of India in the second to the fifth centuries, A.D.
Resident of Newark (New Castle Co.), Del.

Diary maintained daily as a school assignment from 26 March to 30 May 1936, when Campbell was about 15 years old. Initial entries include grades and occasional teacher comments urging Campbell to include more detail. After completing the assignment, Campbell stopped the diary, picking it up again on her own initiative on 1 Jan. 1937 and continuing entries for a year. Topics include schoolwork, recreational activities (walks, bicycle rides, movies, trips to buy ice cream, reading), and family life. Campbell also included maps of her neighborhood, newspaper clippings, and other ephemera. Two legal-sized pages have been removed from the front of the volume; they hold diary entries Campbell maintained separately for 10-28 July 1934.
Bills and receipts of the Carothers Coal Company and other firms, including the Katzenburg Coal Company. The collection also includes two daybooks and two ledgers.
